root.para: Analytical procedures may also be effective in corroborating the occurrence of income and expenses and, sometimes, gains and losses associated with a financial instrument. For example, the absence of a material difference from an expectation that interest income will be a fixed percentage of a debt security based on the effective interest rate when the entity purchased the security provides evidence about the existence of the income (and the security). However, auditors might consider that the income, expenses, gains, and losses associated with a financial instrument may involve a complex interplay of many factors. For example, if the fair value of a derivative is derived from the interrelationship of exchange rates, interest rates, rate differentials, or a combination of these, any attempts to develop an expectation of a financial statement amount may be difficult.
